Posts.Content: Hi all,  I've been taking Anastrozole since Feb of this year, and now for the last 3 months or so I have experienced itching on my arms when I'm too hot. It seems to come on if I've been out and then when I get back indoors. I sometimes have a red rash with this too, but not always. I first noticed it when I got back into my Dad's car after an appointment at the hospital. I notice it when I return home after a walk to the shops. Today I had the same itchy session come on when I had a hot flush indoors, on this occasion I had not been outside. The itch is like a prickly itch which eventualy goes on it's own after I spend time rubbing my arms. The strangest thing is that it only really tends to be on my arms and hands. I have not changed any soaps or washing powders so it can't be that causing it. I have also recently experienced it after getting out of the bath.  Has anybody else experienced this itch whilst taking Anastrozole? It is driving me crazy, and I can't get a quick appointment with my GP.  Thanks in advance. Love Rach xx
Posts.Title: Itching...and I think it's from Anastrozole.

Posts.Content: I'm not sure who I'm better of talking to Helsbels. I've had no joy in talking to anybody regarding my chemo. Even regarding things that I have read on here from other women that have experienced certain things, my consultant always says, "that's unlikely". I feel like shouting at her that if it is unlikely why are so many other ladies experiencing such things. Is your appointment with your consultant really for 1 hour? I only see mine every second chemo cycle, and I'm lucky if that appointment lasts more than 15 minutes. Infact, considering I am about to have cycle 4, I have only seen my consultant once during my whole chemo, and once before chemo actually started. Thanks Helsbels, I will probably ring the chemo suite tomorrow morning xx
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: HI mistymoley, I haven't got any antihistamine at the moment until I can get to see the GP. This itch is definitely something to do with when I get hot. I haven't started any new wash powders or anything.
Posts.Title: Itching...and I think it's from Anastrozole.

Posts.Content: Hi all, with each chemo cycle I have (FEC-T), my veins are becoming more painful. I can see the ridges along my arm, in different places, one of them even going up my upper arm from my elbow joint. I am now unable to fully straighten my arm, and there is a  raised corded vein visible in the elbow joint crease. Is there anything I can do to help ease things?  My arm looks a right state. I still have 3 cycles to go (the T). Thanks in advance xx
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, thanks for your reply. I also had cording in my arm on the surgery side but that is not caused by veins. Nobody informed me of the possibility of this vein cording after chemo. I am due to see my Consultant on Tuesday, I will see what she suggests......probably not a lot as She is pretty useless (Lord knows how she became a Professor).  Rach xx

Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Karen,  I'd like to also add that you can also get a HC2 certificate which entitles you to get money off NHS dental treatment and eye tests, money off glasses/lenses & money off wigs, and refunds of travel costs to receive NHS treatments. (under the low income scheme). You need to fill in form HC1 (which you can order online or get from job centre or hospital), send it off, then you will get your HC"certificate through the post. Order as many of these as poss, I think 5 is the max as your money situation might change more than once. Mine did. I was originally on statutory sick pay from work, then went to ESA of which my payment changed twice. I currently get full help now....FREE DENTAL & EYE TESTS, AND FULL VALUE OF A VOUCHER TOWARDS THE COST OF GLASSES/LENSES, FULL REFUND FOR TRAVEL COSTS.  It all adds up. I have just booked a dental and sight test whilst I can get it free :)  The HC2 certificate lasts for a year, then you can apply again if still needed.  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Paying for Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi, unfortunately my planning of radiotherapy was like yours. I explained that I was struggling with my shoulder, and it was very uncomfortable for me to get my arm into position on the stirrup (I could feel pulling and burning down my upper arm, & pain in my shoulder). They fetched me some painkillers, sat me in the waiting area for 30 mins then tried again. It wasn't much better the second attempt. They gave me 2 options - go back to the physiotherapist and delay the radiotherapy or simply crack on with it. I chose to try it again, and breathed my way through the pain and discomfort.  I have been referred back to the physiotherapist but will only manage to squeeze in 1 session before my radiotherapy date (19 Dec). I am worried that each radiotherapy session will be painful for me, and that is before any soreness occurs from the treatment itself. I think it will be a case of taking strong painkillers before each one, and fingers crossed it will be bearable.  My thoughts are with you, I know exactly what you are going through and the worry you have about the radiotherapy.. WE CAN DO THIS! :)  Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, It's true what Dreamthief stated, you should not be paying for prescriptions. As soon as you werre diagnosed with cancer you should have recieved an Exemption card. You are exempt from paying for prescriptions for 5 years. Talk to you breast care nurse/doctor about this.  Best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Paying for Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi  I had quite a few physio sessions, more so for my shoulder than my arm. I had to have a full lymph node clearance from my armpit, then a drain in for nearly a week. It was during this time that I began to nurse my arm around the drainage bottle in fear of it being tugged (holding my arm in like an 'L' shape). Once the drain had been removed I still held my arm in this position, plus I could not stand the feeling of my arm next to the side of my body as it felt like there was a log there due to the nerve damage. I still do not like the sensation but it's getting better. This 'L' shape has somehow pushed my shoulder forward, as it still is now. I stopped the physio as had to start with chemo and could not juggle both of them.  I continued to do the exercises from the breast surgery but they were not the right kind of exercises to correct my dodgy shoulder position. I think it will take a while to correct that. I have a cream that I was prescribed for nerve pain, maybe you could get some to.  I'm glad your treatment seems to be more bearable for you after taking painkillers, I shall have to do the same thing.  Good luck , Rach xx
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi again,  you could also try Amitriptyline tablets. These are prescribed for nerve pain nowadays. I was advised to take these at night to help me sleep
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza, I'm glad you are feeling more positive now, or should I say thinking more positve. You will never be alone. I wish you all the best for your radiotherapy, and for a great future.  Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Mental Health side effects

Posts.Content: Hi, I just wanted to make you all aware of the 'Vita' magazine incase any of you haven't heard of it. It covers some very interesting subjects and is totally free of charge. Issue 33 was the Spring 2017 issue, and covered care of hands, nails & feet, cancer & work, life after breast cancer, and included spring recipes, and questions & answers about breast cancer. I have found the magazines very interesting and helpful. If you subscribe you will automatically receive the Vita magazine 4 times a year, it can be distributed anywhere in the UK. You can also download the current and past issues from vita.org.uk There are 3 ways to subscribe CALL  0345 092 0808 EMAIL  vita@breastcancercare.org.uk VISIT  vita.org.uk Happy reading, if you are interested Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Vita, The breast cancer magazine.

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar, Thanks for your reply. I finished my chemo end of Oct, so approx 7 months a go.  I didn't have this itchiness all throughout my chemo, but did the flaky scalp. My chemo nurse once told me that it looked like cradle cap.  I washed my hair yesterday using the T-Gel, and for the whole of the day my head was really, really itchy. The itching has calmed down again today but my scalp is still very dry and flaky. I think I should give up on the T-Gel. I have not been using conditioners or styling products for a long time now as my hair is still short.  I think I'll look into the Moogoo. I have my 12 follow-up appointment with my breast care consultant at the end of the month, I'll see what she suggests.  Thanks again Ronstar. I hope I find a solution too :) Rach xx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Reagan,  Thanks for your reply. I was already using Simple shampoo & conditioner throughout my chemo and afterwards. This is when the what looked like cradle cap appeared, and it was my GP who told me to try the T-Gel. I shall try the Simple shampoo again, and see if my head starts to itch after that.  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Helsbels, Thanks for your reply. I'll have a look for that. Is it the same 'Palmers' that make the cocoa butter lotion? I've just had a look on Google, is it the cocoa butter fomula or Olive oil formula that you use? Is it priced at around £4?  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Thank you Puzzler, I think I'll just have to try a few different things to see which works for me xx

Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, Thanks for your reply. I have taken note of your suggestions, I'll have a look for them. My head is not itching today (the day after washing), but still dry & flaky. I'm wondering if I would be better of using an oil, like your daughter does.  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I'm seeking advice on how to treat a dry, flaky, itchy scalp which I've had since chemotherapy. I've spoken to my doctor about it, he advised me to use T-Gel shampoo. I've now been using that for approx 2 months but it doesn't seem to be doing anything. I have just washed my hair again this morning using the T-gel, but my hair seems to itch more now, and when I scratch my head I get dry skin under my nails from my scalp. The itching does seem to settle down after a while from washing but the flakiness doesn't improve.  Does anybody have any other options for me to try please? Preferably options that you know will work.  Thanks in advance, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Dry, flaky, itch scalp since chemo.

Posts.Content: Thanks LondonLass, I definitely needed that supportive hug. I will certainly mention my concerns to the BCN's, and hopefully it won't be too bad for me. I'm worrying about my frozen shoulder as well as the tender boob.......then of course there's the results. Do you know if they typically tell you the results whilst you're there or do you have to go back for them?  Rach xx
Posts.Title: First Surveillance Mammogram after diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Thank you Chloecat45,  I will certainly explain my concerns before they start, and I hope they listen to me. Does this tenderness ever go?  All the best for you for July too. Rach xx
Posts.Title: First Surveillance Mammogram after diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi everybody, Well tomorrow I have my first surveillance mammogram, and to say I am nervous would be an understatement. My boob is still tender, I have a frozen shoulder, and I'm worrying about everything. I'm fed up of having to get my boob out, and having to put on hospital gowns. Even the idea of going back to the breast clinic where I was diagnosed terrifies me. Horrible memories have come floating back into my head. How do I mentally prepare myself for this mammogram? I know I won't sleep tonight worrying about tomorrow.  Rach xx
Posts.Title: First Surveillance Mammogram after diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass, thank goodness that is over and done with. It was even worse than I imagined it to be, and certainly different to the mammogram I had for diagnosis. The nurse kept telling me to stick my bottom out, twist my hip this way and that way. I never had to do any of that before. She never told me to hold the handle things, which I did at my first mammogram last year.  I felt like I was in there for ages.  As for the results, she said I will receive them in 3-4 weeks. I have an appointment to see my breast care consultant in June.  I've also received a letter to make an appointment for my routine smear test...............when will I be left alone? lol  Thanks again LondonLass, Rach  xxx
Posts.Title: First Surveillance Mammogram after diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi,  I suffered terribly with vein problems during my chemo. I had 6 FEC-T, and I was effected during both the FEC and the T.  I was never advised to have a line put in. I am now nearly 2 months post chemo and my veins are an absolute mess on ny chemo arm. I am unable to straighten that arm, and when I try I experience a painful pulling sensation in my arm joint (front of elbow) and down my arm where the unsightly veins are. I have never been told to do anything to help this, even though I have recently shown my arm to the Profs/Onco.  Exercising has not improved my veins at all, but it is very important that you keep up with your excersise the best you can.  Other than using a pain relieving gel/cream I don't think there is much else you can do.  Maybe it is worth you asking for a PICC line if you think your veins will get worse. Best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: Hi Frances, Many people have used the R1 & R2 but it really isn't necessary. I, Like many used an Aloe Vera gel, infact it was an aftersun gel which I already had at home, and I had no problems whatsoever. The R1 & R2 are expensive for the NHS, whereas the gel I used only cost a couple of £'s.  All the best with your radiotherapy. Love Rach xx
Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Thanks Carol, I really don't know what I need to ask as I don';t know anything about the PICC line or what it involves. What do you mean about the bath being easier to keep it dry? Rach xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks LondonLass, the nurses at the hospital already suggested it today, but didn't give me any info regarding it. I'm not sure now if they meant a PICC or the Hickman Line, both were mentioned. I know they are similar. xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Ok thanks Skye, I prefer a bath anyway. I will ask all those questions if I need to have a line fitted, which I am thinking I will. I think it's going to be a struggle with my chemo tomorrow with having awkward veins. Thanks again Skye XX
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Yesterday I went to my GP surgery to have my pre chemo bloods taken. It took the nurse and a doctor 3 attempts to get any blood out of me. On seeing my consultant at the hospital today I was told that all my bloods were ok, but the one for my platelets was still pending. Two hours after leaving the hospital a nurse rings me stating that the blood for my platelets had congealed or something, and that I now need to have more blood taken. Back to the hospital I go, and 2hrs later, with having 2 different departments trying to get blood, and with 3 different nurses trying, using different areas on my arm, wrist and hand, they only managed to get a capful. None of us have any idea whether this is enough to test my platelets, so not sure if my chemo will go ahead tomorrow. The nurses spoke about me having a PICC Line inserted now. Do/did any of you have one? This is grossing me out a bit. xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks Carol, I don't think I have much option but to have a line fitted. I'll see what happens when I go for my chemo tomorrow. Rach xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you LondonLass, it was suggested to me today, but I wasn't told anything about it as such other than it threads from your arm up to near your heart. I wasn't aware it needed flushing every week. How do they do that? I am about to have my 2nd cycle of FEC T tomorrow, 4 more to follow, and my veins are already playing up.
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you Skye, The Hickman line was also an option put to me today, but again nobody went into ant detail about that either. xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Neither of them sound very nice to me Skye, but if I need one then so be it! All I know is my hand is so painful now after being stabbed so many times over the past 2 days xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I finished chemo (FEC-T) at the end of October 2016. My veins are still in a mess, I can not completely straighten my chemo arm because the vein running through my elbowpit (inner side to elbow) is rock hard.  There has been no improvement at all since I finished my chemo approx 6 months ago. It looks worse if I twist my arm. Is anybody else suffering with this?  Does it ever recover? Is there anything I can do to improve it?   Thanks, Rach xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi again Flopsyuk, I understand now about you saying both arms. Yes I have also been doing my post surgery exercises each day. I still managed to get a frozen shoulder during radiotherapy. I now have to see a Shoulder specialist. I also had cording after surgery, but this is definitely my veins.  Hopefully you will have more joy than me in getting some answers. Rach xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Jaki17, One of my veins has showed signs of damage since my first ever chemo, and the rest of my veins followed suit throughout. The whole of the bottom part of my arm to just past my elbow crease is full of ugly looking indents. They are quite unsightly. Not particularly painful.  I was told to use Ibuprofen gel also, that is ok for any pain but will not solve the issue. I had my first chemo July 3rd, my last on 26th Oct, so I'm now approx 6 months post chemo with no improvement whatsoever.  Good luck with the 'T', and I hope your veins hold out. Oh the joys of having chemo!  Best wishes to you, Rach xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Mistymoley, The bit in my elbowpit does look and feel like cording but I thought cording would only happen on surgery side after lymph node removal. This is on my chemo arm, and the mess down my arm does not look like cording. I was already having physio on my frozen shoulder (surgery side), my Onco told me to ask my therapist for some gentle stretching exercises to help with my arm. The physiotherapist just told me to use a bag of sugar. I have now been discharged from physio as I need to see a shoulder specialist instead, as my shoulder was not improving.  I have my 1 year follow up appoinment with my breast care consultant/surgeon in June, I shall show her and see what she suggests.  Everybody else either has not answer or just fobs me off.
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Jan13, I was told to hold the bag of sugar in my hand then bend my arm up and then let it go down by my side. I think the weight of the sugar was supposed to stretch the veins.  Was your massage for your chemo arm? Rach xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi Maxine,  I can't even explain to you what has physically happened to my veins because I don't know myself. I have ugly ridges/indents down my arm. I'm not sure if this is from my veins collapsing or hardening.  I've shown it to my GP & Onco but neither ever explained what had happened, just told me that chemo drugs damage your veins lol (as if I hadn't realised). I've tried simple stretching exercises which my physio told me to do, but still no improvement was so ever. I tried to add a pic of my arm but kept getting a message come up about the file size when I tried to post.  Hopefully someone will have some answers xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hi there FlopsyUK,  How come you are suffering this in both arms? That must be a nightmare for you.  Your Oncologist is as helpful as mine. They obviously don't really care. I was having physio on my frozen shoulder, my physiotherapist just told me to hold a bag of sugar and keep naturally bending and straightening my arm, with the hope of stretching the vien. That has done nothing at all for me. I've even carried heavy shopping with that arm....and again, nothing.  Chemo is nasty, hey. I hope we can find a solution soon. I'll await your update.  Thanks, best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Hurrah! Such brilliant news Sophie. Best wishes, love Rach xx
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hurrah! Such brilliant news Sophie. Best wishes, love Rach xx
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hi, I had lumpectomy & Lymph clearance May-June 2016, I had my 1 year mammogram June 2017, which was clear. I also get aches and pain in my boob. I can't wait to take my bra of at the end of the day, and I only have small boobs. Radiotherapy makes things tight/painful.  Best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: I had lumpectomy mid Dec 16 for DCIS grade 2 no lymph nodes involved...

Posts.Content: Hi,  I had a hoarse, broken voice during my chemo. I can't remember having a sore throat with it though.
Posts.Title: Lost my voice

Posts.Content: Thank you very much Kerry, I have left you a PM my lovely. Hope you are doing well xxxx
Posts.Title: FEC-T chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I am due to have my first chemo session next week. I am still trying to understand the cycles. I will receive 6 cycles at 21 day intervals, what does this mean exactly? Thanks in advance xx
Posts.Title: FEC-T chemo.

Posts.Content: Jeanie, thank you for your reply. Everything you sad was true for me too. I had my first cycle yesterday, cool cap included lol I feel fine today so far, got the pink wee, taking the tablets as you said I would. I have to do the injection on Sunday for 5 days. The district nurse is coming to do do the first one as I'm not feeling confident about doing it myself.  I learned more from your reply than what I did through the nurses and doctors. They seem to think I already know everything. Thanks again Jeanie, I hope you are doing well yourself. Hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: FEC-T chemo.

Posts.Content: I meant a blood thinning tablet like Warfarin?  Did you need these after you'de completed the Fragmin injections?  Would I be able to take Letrozole if it turns out that I am not post menopausal though? (as these are for women who have been through the menopause already). This is what I am trying to find out. 1) am I menopausal/post menopausal?  2) What do I take if I am not, and can not take Tamoxifen?
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you Julia,  yes I meant hormone therapy not HRT.  No doubt the Onco will recommend the FSH test, if not I will mention it myself.  You mentioned the 2 drugs, Tamoxifen & Leftozole depending on whether a person is pre or post menopausal. That is what I am querying because I will not be able to have Tamoxifen if I am pre menopausal due to the blood clot, so what then?  You're damn right about the Fragmin injections. They sure do sting and cause bruising. I have started to inject my thighs now instead of my stomach, and it's not so bad. The key is to inject slowly. How long did you need the fragmin for, and did you need to go onto a tablet form after the injections? Thanks Julia, best wishes to you  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you LondonLass,  I'm assuming they will offer me the blood test then. When does hormone therapy start, after radiotherapy?  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Thank you LondonLass,  wishing you all the best too :) xx
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Hi all, I am often asked by the medical team when I had my last period. My reply is 'I do not know as I was on the mini pill before being diagnosed with breast cancer, so obviously did not have periods'. I am 47 years old, stopped my contraceptive pill back in May but still have not had a period. I have heard that chemotherapy can stop them (of which I had), but how do I know if I am actually menopausal or not??  I am currently having daily injections of Fragmin as was diagnosed with a blood clot in my leg just over a month ago, I have to inject myself for at least 3 months. Because of the blood clot my Onco consultant informed me that I would not be able to have Tamoxifen for my HRT as that can cause blood clots, so would have to take something else (I can not remember the name of it).  My question is, how do they know what HRT drug to put me on if I and they do not know if I am menopausal or not?  Does the HRT start after Rads?  Thanks , Rach xx
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar, thanks for your reply. You stated that they offered you Anastrozole, were you post-menopausal? I ask this as it is not an effective treatment while the ovaries are still producing oestrogen, but I read that it is sometimes given alongside another drug called Goserelin which stops the ovaries working.  It was my medical Oncologist who told me that I would not be given Tamoxifen because I have a blood clot already. I'm assuming they willo just have to give me the blood test (GRRRRRRR! Another needle! GRRRRRRRRRRR! More blood! ) Thanks anyway Ronstar, best wishes to you  Rach xx
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Anne,  It is very hard having to wait for results. I recently had my 1 year mammogram and was told the results would be between 3 - 4 weeks, but they actually came after 5 weeks. I hated that wait, and thought it very cruel considering all I had already been through. I did ring my GP surgery to see if they had received their copy of my results, and was a tad relieved that they hadn't.  I shall certainly be telling my breast care consultant about the horrendous wait. I hope you get yours soon. Best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Hi, I also had FEC-T, and it really isn't that bad. I was dreading it once I was told that I would need chemo, even more so after watching my mother go through it when I was in my teens (back in the early 80's). My mother was very sick throughout and really did look poorly with it. I know we all have different side effects, but I managed my chemo very well. Yes I had times when I felt nauseous, and I had the typical aches and tiredness, but it is all very do-able. You will be given anti-sickness medication which certainly must help with the nausea. You will see your oncologist before each chemo cycle.....this is your time to let them know how you are managing it all. They will prescribe you any medication that will help with any side effects. I had a sore mouth & dry eyes during 'T', so was prescribed a mouth wash & eye drops. You may find that each cycle brings differing side effects......I think this may be typical.  I don't know if you've considered using the cold cap. I used it throughout my chemo and managed to keep the majority of my hair.  I wish you all the best, please enjoy your holiday, and I hope that you can find things to do to take your mind off of the chemo. Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Terrified of starting chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, I also had FEC-T, and it really isn't that bad. I was dreading it once I was told that I would need chemo, even more so after watching my mother go through it when I was in my teens (back in the early 80's). My mother was very sick throughout and really did look poorly with it. I know we all have different side effects, but I managed my chemo very well. Yes I had times when I felt nauseous, and I had the typical aches and tiredness, but it is all very do-able. You will be given anti-sickness medication which certainly must help with the nausea. You will see your oncologist before each chemo cycle.....this is your time to let them know how you are managing it all. They will prescribe you any medication that will help with any side effects. I had a sore mouth & dry eyes during 'T', so was prescribed a mouth wash & eye drops. You may find that each cycle brings differing side effects......I think this may be typical.  I don't know if you've considered using the cold cap. I used it throughout my chemo and managed to keep the majority of my hair.  I wish you all the best, please enjoy your holiday, and I hope that you can find things to do to take your mind off of the chemo. Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Terrified of starting chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, I have had a stiffish shoulder since having axillary node clearance which became worse during radiotherapy. I am having physiotherapy for this. My shoulder is so painful, with a pain that goes all the way to just above my elbow.  My question is, would I be OK to have a Cortisone injection in my shoulder on surgery side, does this increase Lymphedema risk? Has anybody had this done please? Thanks, Rach xx Let's stay strong together!
Posts.Title: Frozen shoulder, Cortisone injection, lymphedema risk.

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, I hope you are enjoying your time in Croatia. Chemo really isn't THAT bad. I was horrified when told I needed it, but it really is do-able. Many of us on here have also had FEC-T, and you'll probably find we all have different tales to tell about it, but we've survived it :) Once you've got your first one out of the way, you'll be on a roll.  You'll always find someone on here for advice, to rant at, or just to talk to.  Good luck for the 10th Jo. Love & hugs, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Start FEC-T May 10th

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha, I hope you are doing ok. Abraxane & Docetaxel are both 'Taxanes' so I'm assuming they would be very similar, and that the cold cap would work the same with both. I had Docetaxel, and found that I had less hair loss than with 'FEC', hopefully it will be the same for you. I have even read that some people notice their hair growing during 'T'. I also used the cold cap throughout my chemo.  I found this info from a site - 'Even with breast cancers, the effectiveness of scalp cooling depends on the type of chemotherapy regimen. Patients receiving medication from the taxane-class (like Taxol, Taxotere and Abraxane) usually fare better than those treated with anthracycline-based chemotherapy (like Adriamycin, Ellence and Daunorubicin), which is more aggressive in causing rapid and complete hair loss.' So from that, I would personally be feeling positive about 'Abrazane'. I hope that helps you a little.  All the best Sacha, love Rach xx
Posts.Title: Abraxane and hair loss with cold cap

Posts.Content: You're very welcome Sacha, I had a few wobbles throughout my journey, and even a year on I don't feel like my old self yet. I'm not even sure if I ever will again. I found the whole journey mentally exhausting, and it's still hard to admit all that I have been through, and to actually accept it. It is easier for me to talk about now, but it still upsets me, and I still have the odd weepy session.  I'm here if you ever ever need to talk, or you can always leave me a personal message if you prefer.  All the best Sacha, love Rach xx
Posts.Title: Abraxane and hair loss with cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi Millie, I have just had my 3rd radiotherapy today and so far so good.  I have read and been told that any soreness/discolouration will be more likely between week 2 and 3.  I have not been given any creams but was told to use E45. I have read different stories on the forums on here about different creams etc.   I have been told to use the cream twice a day, morning and before bed. (more if sore and want to use it more)., and that I do not have to wash it off before treatment.  I have been told to apply to whole of the breast, the collarbone and the back of my shoulder as I am slim. (treatment given to breast and collarbone). I have been told to wash with an unpurfumed soap, like Simple. Do not rub too hard, and only pat dry.   Good luck with the rest of your treatment, Rach xx
Posts.Title: creams to use

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas to you too, and everyone xx
Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Hi, I have recently had my first councelling session with the genetics team as my mother had breast cancer at 41, her sister also had it, as did her daughter.  There is the BRCA 1 & BRCA 2 gene. I am also being tested for other genes that are responsible for a person developing breast cancer and other cancers such as TP53, PALB2, PTEN, STK11 & CDH1. This is because there are a lot of different cancers on both sides of my family.  It is important to understand that a woman who inherited an altered copy of a gene may not necessarily go on to develop cancer in her life but her chance of developing cancer is increased. The BRCA genes can affect males aswell as females. There's breast & ovarian cancer in women, & breast & prostate cancer in men. So If I do have the altered gene then there is a 50% chance that my Son also has it, and my Grandsons.  My blood has been taken to check for all the possible altered genes, and I will recieve an appointment to return to see my genetics counsellor when she has the results which should be within 2 to 3 months time. It is a very expensive test.  I think you should definitely talk to your oncologist. They will be able to refer you to the genetics team.  All the best, Rach xx
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Hi Ladyinred, Thanks for your reply. I have no idea what is going on with my arm. It only hurts when I stretch my arm out, and to actually lock my elbow out is so so painful. I can't see or feel any cording though. I am still trying to do the exercises but I've had a frozen shoulder for months too. I have been waiting to see a shoulder specialist since February now as physio wasn't improving it. The NHS can sometimes be a joke!  Getting to see the GP is easier said than done but I think I will have to try to get an appointment. Best wishes to you, Rach xx
Posts.Title: Pain running down surgery-side arm.

Posts.Content: Hi Sal, thanks for your reply. It seems to be one thing after another for me........ waiting to see a shoulder specialist as had a frozen shoulder since Feb. (physio discharged me as not helping) waiting for a scan on my liver as my bloods show raised liver enzymes & low platelets. Have to have 3 monthly appointments at the eye clinic as something is visible on the back of my left eyeball.  waiting for appointment at balance clinic as I feel unsteady on my feet. veins buggered from chemo, so hard to get blood for tests.  still not sleeping good at night ....and now this pain in my arm. There is nothing at all visible in my arm, nor can I feel anything there, just pain when I stretch that arm out and pain when I then touch it. I am also thinking it must be cording but not 100% sure. I think I'll have to try to get an appointment to see my GP (easier said than done). Then probably a wait of 3 months to get to see a physiotherapist if that is required.  I hope you are doing OK Sal, Much love, Rach xx

Posts.Content: Hi Zanib, it sounds like your shopping trip and lunch today was just what was needed. I'm so glad you had a nice time. Let's keep positive together. Love, hugs and best wishes to you xxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi, I am coming up to 15 months post surgery (lumpectomy & axillary node clearance), and for a few days now I have pain when I straighten my arm which runs from the inner top, along elbow crease down the inner bottom of my arm. It does feel like a tightness when I straighten my arm fully and the pain is horrible. It's hard for me to tell if my arm is swollen, it may be a little. Could this pain be a nerve pain? Could this be Lymphedema? Could it be cording? I don't know if cording is a physical thing that I should be able to see, but there is nothing I can see out of the ordinary here.  I don't know what to do, any suggestions would be appreciated please.  Thanks, Rach xx

Posts.Content: Excellent news Sophie. I'm so pleased for you :) xx

Posts.Content: Oh London Lass,  I loved reading the Olympic Events, boy did I laugh lol. Thank you.  I can relate to all of them apart from event 2, I do not sweat, just feel uncomfortably hot and stuffy headed as if I need fresh air.  The strangest thing is throughout my hot flusters my feet remain ice cold, unless I am in bed.  2 more EVENTS - Thermostat up, thermostat down.        Window open, window closed Thanks for the entertainment. What a great team we are.........between us we WOULD win gold at all these EVENTS. :) :)  XXXX
Posts.Title: NOT Pink and Fluffy! RETURNS....

Posts.Content: Hi Cuckoo,  I had lumpectomy and lymph node clearance during May & June 2016, finished chemo Oct 2016, finished rads Jan 2017. I had my 1 year mammogram May 2017, and have my 1 year appointment with my breast care consultant next week (end of June 2017). I have an appointment already booked with my oncologist for Feb 2019, which will be approx 2 yrs since finishing treatment. I am on Anastrozole for 5 yrs.  You stated you have 6 monthly checks at your BC unit, whereas mine are yearly. So all hospitals work differently. Maybe you will receive an appointment to see your onologist at some point down the line.  Love & best wishes, Rach xx
Posts.Title: 2 yrs post-treatment, should I still be seeing Oncologist?
